block.p: Two articles on Aug. 28 - ''Fighting the Greenhouse Effect,'' by Matthew L. Wald, and ''It's Time to Plan a Third World Revival,'' by J. D. Robinson 3d, chief executive of American Express - ruined my day. Not because their respective subjects were unimportant or badly treated, but because the authors ignored in one case a major cause and in the other a major solution.

Mr. Robinson rightly sees the need to fuel the development of third world nations by bringing to manageable levels their foreign debt servicing and by injecting new capital needed to maintain economic growth.

But he deliberately ignores the fact that the real problem of third world nations is their constant decapitalization. The capital generated by the functioning of their governments, by public and private indebtedness and by private economic activities is not reinvested, as it should be, in the generating countries. A large portion of it flies away - ''flight capital.''

In discussing the greenhouse effect, Mr. Wald rightly defines the extreme gravity of carbon dioxide emissions and realistically relates it to the burning of fossil fuels, of which petroleum is the worst culprit.

But Mr. Wald totally ignores a major solution like alcohol - ethanol. When mixed with gasoline, it burns cleanly and efficiently, and offers the most realistic way of creating rewarding jobs in most of the underdeveloped countries of the world.

What's needed to solve these worldwide problems - underdevelopment and contamination of the environment - is an international unbiased approach that will result in international enforceable laws that in both cases, and among other provisions, will control the greed and selfishness of the two major culprits: the banking and the petroleum industries. JUAN RIOS Miami, Aug. 28
